title: How to Clean Suede Gloves

steps.headline: Check your gloves’ care tags.
steps.description: Before you begin cleaning your suede gloves, check the care tags. There are a lot of different types of suede and suede finishes, and each type has different care needs. The tags should tell you the best process for cleaning your type of suede. For example, you should not use water on very fine suede, since the water will likely stain it. Other types of suede should only ever be cleaned with a suede eraser or brush and never any type of liquid.

steps.headline: Work the nap up.
steps.description: The nap in suede is what makes it look smooth, but you need to work it up in order to clean it properly. Run a suede brush or bath towel against the grain of your suede gloves. Start at the wrist of your glove and use short strokes, moving up the length of the glove.

steps.headline: Use a suede eraser to remove stains and marks.
steps.description: Rub your suede eraser back and forth over stains and marks on your gloves. Start by rubbing gently. If you notice that the stains or marks aren't coming up, slowly begin to apply more pressure as you rub the eraser back and forth. The suede eraser should bring up most of the marks and stains on your gloves. If you don’t have a suede eraser, you can use a small pencil eraser for this step. You might notice that some eraser material comes off on the suede. This is normal, and you should be able to brush it right off of your gloves.

steps.headline: Rewet the stain.
steps.description: If your suede gloves are work or gardening gloves, they probably have old water stains on them. To get rid of those stains, start by rewetting your gloves completely. The best way to do this is to run your gloves under a faucet. This ensures an even application of water, which can prevent water stains after this process is over.

steps.headline: Blot up the water.
steps.description: Use paper towel to blot up the water by pressing down on your gloves. Don’t push down too hard, as this can actually force stains further into the suede. Use only slightly more pressure than you would get from resting your hand on top of your gloves.

steps.headline: Let the gloves air dry completely.
steps.description: Once you’ve blotted up the water, let your gloves air dry completely. Don’t put them in the dryer, as this will cause your gloves to shrink. You might need to use a suede brush or paper towel to fluff up the suede once they are dry.

methods.name: Using Vinegar to Get Rid of Stubborn Stains

steps.headline: Dampen a cotton cloth with vinegar.
steps.description: Dip a clean cotton cloth into white distilled vinegar. Don’t use apple cider vinegar as this will stain the suede.

steps.headline: Press the cloth onto the stain.
steps.description: Using gentle pressure, press the cloth onto the stain(s) you’re trying to remove. Don’t press too hard as this will push the stain into the suede.

steps.headline: Gently rub the cloth across the stains.
steps.description: After you’ve pressed down on the stain, wipe the cloth gently across the stain and against the grain. This gets the nap up and allows the vinegar to work into the stain itself.

steps.headline: Let the gloves dry.
steps.description: After you’ve pressed and wiped the gloves with vinegar, let them dry completely. Until the gloves are dry, you won’t be able to tell if the stains have been completely removed.

steps.headline: Repeat as necessary.
steps.description: Depending on the stain, you might need to repeat this step more than once. The gloves must dry completely in between each step.
